content.description: This route has parallel seams on gently overhanging rock.
content.protection: Micro through three quarter. Some fixed wires.
content.location:
This is left of

Withholding Evidence

.

content.description: This route has a wonderful steep technical crux made even more exciting since much of the crux is protected by a cam.  The upper 2/3's of the route is pretty uneventful moderate 5th class climbing.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a #1 Camalot.  2 open coldshuts at the top.
content.location:
This route is located to the left of "

I'll be Black

" just before the wall turns the corner.

content.description: This is a fun route with varied climbing and some interesting moves. Begin by climbing up a slab with a couple bolts and then transition into a steep, left-angling corner with a couple more bolts and some cam placements.
content.protection: 4 bolts and some small cams. There are 2 open coldshuts at the top.
content.location: This is the route farthest right at Sunset Cliff.

content.description: This fantastic route goes directly up the large dihedral to the right of The Avenger. "A Bold Lead" states Tom's guidebook, the crux felt to be mantling the small roof as you leave the slab and enter the corner, but it's well protected. The rest of the route is sustained and fun climbing. While there are likely ways to do this route with a 60m rope a 70m is much more comfortable for everybody involved, this holds true for the other routes to the right as well.
content.protection: Cams to 2" and small stoppers, chains at the top.
content.location: The large dihedral to the right of the Avenger. If you choose to belay from the bottom of the slab you will need a 70m rope.

content.description: This has fun fingers to fist climbing on a face crack and in a corner to work your way out a short roof and clip the chains.
content.protection: Standard rack of cams to 3" and stoppers will suffice, a #4 is optional.
content.location:
This is the obvious, slabby corner directly [right] of the bolted black streak (

I'll Be Black

).  It requires the same "4th" class scramble to the ledge to belay as

I'll Be Black

.

content.description:
Squeeze Please climbs the obvious, right-facing dihedral on the lower left section of Sunset Cliff.

The crux is climbing past the second bolt. After that, it is gear protected for the remainder of the route.
content.protection: 2 bolts, then small to medium-sized cams.
content.location:
This is left of

Wrong Side of the Tracks

and just right of the bolted arete, Hasta la Vista. The route is marked by a large, right-facing dihedral with 2 bolts.

content.description: This has steep climbing into a small dihedral with several insecure sections.  It may feel pretty hard or even desperate for 11b depending on how you climb it.
content.protection: Bolts (I think there were 7 bolts) to a chain anchor.
content.location:
It is the next route left of "

Unnecessary Buffness

".

content.description: This is an excellent, thin face climb which climbs the obvious black streak. A few thin moves at 2/3rds height provide the crux.
content.location: This is located above a ledge system approximately 30' above the base of the crag - it requires a short 4th-class scramble to reach the base.

content.description: This has two bolts on the arÃªte. It is tricky to figure for the onsight. Hasta La Vista is excellent for its movements and elusiveness.
content.protection: A few cams, some 0.2/0.3 and 0.75/1, and two bolts.
content.location: This is on the left and lower part of Sunset Cliff in a right-facing corner.

content.description: This stunning crack and face route is perhaps the best single trad pitch I've done in Colorado. Overhanging and sustained with a crux throw at 2/3rds height. It was a long time project first attempted by Jeff Hollenbaugh in the early 90s on gear. It was then bolted and projected by Tom Perkins, but still remained unclimbed. After climbing the route on gear, and receiving Tom's permission, I removed the unnecessary bolts. (There are still a few bolts that need to be removed as of 6/27/06). The route may be a bit soft for .13a, perhaps .12+, but needs a repeat to confirm the grade.
content.protection: Placing the gear on this route is a definite crux. Although never dangerous the route requires a go-for-it attitude. A single set of cams from a #0 TCU to a #4 Camalot, one extra #4 Camalot, and a small wire or two will see you to the anchors. There is a fixed wire at the top of the initial fist crack--the climbing to here is worthwhile .12a. There are chain anchors at the top of the route, which are accessible to set up a toprope (with a little scrambling).
content.location:
This starts off the same ledge as

I'll Be Black

, in the middle portion of Sunset Cliff.

content.description:
This is a short, power-packed, little corner route with some techno-stemming! I think this rig is one of the steller trad testpieces of the grade, on The Pass.

It has a well-protected (get that gear in just right!), hard start to short but sustained laybacking in the tight corner. I gave it an "R" rating, but that's dependent on what gear you've got - there's this one tricky spot where only just the right brand and size cam placed a certain way will work...okay. If that piece blows, you'd better have a great belayer!!!
content.protection: See the description...but for a recommendation/comparison purposes: blue Alien - #2 Friend, medium nuts, a medium (#7 or 8) Hex works. Double open shut anchor.
content.location: This is the farthest left route on Sunset Cliff, the leftmost, clean dihedral without bolts.
